articles.headline: Interest Rates on Italian Bonds Pushed to New Levels
articles.snippet: Bond rates are being driven to levels that earlier forced Greece, Ireland and Portugal to seek bailouts.
articles.abstract: Bond rates are being driven to levels that earlier forced Greece, Ireland and Portugal to seek bailouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the endgame near for Italy?

articles.headline: Businesses Feel the Pinch as China Tightens Lending
articles.snippet: China’s policy makers have created an artificial credit crunch in order to keep inflation in check, biting into business growth, real estate prices and lending.
articles.abstract: China’s policy makers have created an artificial credit crunch in order to keep inflation in check, biting into business growth, real estate prices and lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — David Huan had big dreams for his business, a factory in central China that makes picture frames ranging from glossy wood to the gilded and baroque. He wanted to expand production, and add new equipment and 400 to 600 workers atop the 400 he already employed.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Syria Unleashes Assault to Take an Unbowed City
articles.snippet: The government has launched an assault to retake Homs, in possibly one of the most violent episodes in the uprising.
articles.abstract: The government has launched an assault to retake Homs, in possibly one of the most violent episodes in the uprising.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government has launched a bloody assault to retake Homs, the country’s third-largest city, facing armed defectors who have prevented the government’s forces from seizing it as they did other restive locales this summer, in what may stand as one of the most violent episodes in an eight-month uprising.

articles.headline: Doctor Is Guilty in Michael Jackson’s Death
articles.snippet: Dr. Conrad Murray was convicted for administering the drug that helped kill the pop star in June 2009.
articles.abstract: Dr. Conrad Murray was convicted for administering the drug that helped kill the pop star in June 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Michael Jackson, among the most famous performers in pop music history, spent his final days in a sleep-deprived haze of medication and misery until finally succumbing to a fatal dose of potent drugs provided by the private physician he had hired to act as his personal pharmaceutical dispensary, a jury decided on Monday.

articles.headline: At Sony Music, a Plan to Dominate the Industry
articles.snippet: Doug Morris, the new chief of Sony Music Entertainment, says his goal is to “create the pre-eminent record company in the world.”
articles.abstract: Doug Morris, the new chief of Sony Music Entertainment, says his goal is to “create the pre-eminent record company in the world.”
articles.lead_paragraph: A huge self-portrait of Bono hangs in the Madison Avenue office of Doug Morris, the new chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment, and on a nearby table sit his snapshots, arm-in-arm with Tupac Shakur and Snoop Dogg. Along with a determination to dominate the music industry, Mr. Morris brought them from his last job as head of the Universal Music Group.

articles.headline: High Bank Fees Give Wal-Mart a Money Aisle
articles.snippet: Fed up with banks, many consumers now use Wal-Mart to cash their paychecks, pay bills or buy a prepaid debit card — all at significantly lower costs.
articles.abstract: Fed up with banks, many consumers now use Wal-Mart to cash their paychecks, pay bills or buy a prepaid debit card — all at significantly lower costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: DICKSON CITY, Pa. — Americans say they are fed up with banks. They are protesting on Wall Street and raising a ruckus over outsize fees. Now there is a surprising beneficiary: Wal-Mart.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Woman Accuses Cain of Groping; He Denies Charge
articles.snippet: Herman Cain said he would offer a defense on Tuesday against allegations that he made an unwanted physical advance on Sharon Bialek in 1997.
articles.abstract: Herman Cain said he would offer a defense on Tuesday against allegations that he made an unwanted physical advance on Sharon Bialek in 1997.
articles.lead_paragraph: Putting a face and a name for the first time to accusations of sexual harassment against the Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain, a woman stepped forward on Monday to say that Mr. Cain made an unwanted physical advance on her 14 years ago when he was the chief of the National Restaurant Association.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: In Turmoil, Greece and Italy Deepen Euro Crisis
articles.snippet: The prospect of a new transitional government in Greece and signs that Silvio Berlusconi’s hold on power in Italy was weakening did little to reassure investors.
articles.abstract: The prospect of a new transitional government in Greece and signs that Silvio Berlusconi’s hold on power in Italy was weakening did little to reassure investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — With political turmoil still plaguing Greece and descending upon the much larger economy of Italy on Monday, the fate of the euro and market stability worldwide hinged on whether two of Europe’s most tangled and unresponsive political cultures could deal with their tightening fiscal gridlock.

articles.headline: Promises Made, and Remade, by Firms in S.E.C. Fraud Cases
articles.snippet: An analysis of enforcement actions found at least 51 cases in which 19 Wall Street firms had broken antifraud laws they had agreed never to breach.
articles.abstract: An analysis of enforcement actions found at least 51 cases in which 19 Wall Street firms had broken antifraud laws they had agreed never to breach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Citigroup agreed last month to pay $285 million to settle civil charges that it had defrauded customers during the housing bubble, the Securities and Exchange Commission wrested a typical pledge from the company: Citigroup would never violate one of the main antifraud provisions of the nation’s securities laws.

articles.headline: Olympus Hid Investing Losses in Big Merger Payouts
articles.snippet: The revelation that more than $1 billion in merger payouts were used to hide losses could make the Olympus scandal one of the biggest cases of accounting fraud in corporate history.
articles.abstract: The revelation that more than $1 billion in merger payouts were used to hide losses could make the Olympus scandal one of the biggest cases of accounting fraud in corporate history.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Olympus said Tuesday that more than $1 billion in merger payouts were used to hide years of losses on investments, an acknowledgment that is an abrupt about-face for the company, which had denied any wrongdoing in the wake of a widening scandal.

articles.headline: European Debt Crisis as Berlusconi’s Last Stand
articles.snippet: Silvio Berlusconi’s offer to step aside came after a humiliating vote in Parliament and a demand by a key ally that he resign for the sake of the country.
articles.abstract: Silvio Berlusconi’s offer to step aside came after a humiliating vote in Parliament and a demand by a key ally that he resign for the sake of the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — The European debt crisis appeared to claim its most prominent victim on Tuesday when Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, cornered by world markets and humiliated by a parliamentary setback, pledged to resign after Italy’s Parliament passes austerity measures demanded by the European Union.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Elisabetta Povoledo
